values:
Ivanhoe, Texas, USA - September 2005

East Texas is home to many friendly people, many attractive communities and some of the most active white supremacists in the United States. It is interesting, therefore, that as Alabama state senator Hank Erwin vociferously called Hurricane Katrina God's wrath upon hedonists and sinners, he made no mention of what Hurricane Rita was divine retribution for.

However, if it was the action of an angry deity, it is hard to believe the correct targets were hit. I went to the sections of east Texas that were hardest hit by Rita less than a week after she finally dissipated over the Midwest. The city of Beaumont was battered and the coastal towns of Bridge City and Port Arthur were flattened by the wind. Sabine Pass, where the eye had come ashore, was nearly wiped away.

Fortunately for east Texas, many elements of FEMA, the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and the Southern Baptist Convention were already in the area tending to Katrina victims and moved ably to help those newly in need. The most serious part of Rita's destruction was the swath of small towns north of Sabine Pass that were thrashed and nearly buried. Several hamlets, with population in the double digits, were cut off as roads, rail and telephone lines were destroyed by winds and the trees it felled. The townspeople who remained in their homes after the alerts were reduced to living off what supplies they had on hand until rescuers and aid workers penetrated the mess.

Many troops of the Texas National Guard, including some who were also tending to the destruction of their own property, were called up to help distribute supplies. Leaving from the Beaumont command center, several men and women trucked north to the towns still paralyzed. I was in a Jeep with a sergeant from Houston. He told me that many black youths from the large cities of Texas choose the National Guard as a way to pay for education and make a better life. As such, he and the other black Guardsmen make up a disproportionately high part of the force. This is all well and good at home or even in their posting abroad, but many of them had never dealt with the race problems that surface in rural east Texas.

Near the tiny town of Ivanhoe, we stopped at a general store where half a dozen people were working furiously to reopen. The sergeant and a few troops dismounted and lifted a few ice bags out of the back. They carried them into the store to the thanks of the owned and they chatted for a few minutes. As we were ready to leave, a monster truck, taller than it was wide, with a Confederate flag in the window pulled up recklessly behind the jeep, blocking us in. A ragged man with long hair and a scruffy beard jumped out.

To my knowledge, I had never seen a Klansmen before. He had no bifurcated tail, cloven hoofs or trident. He was just a man, but a mean-looking one at that. He wore a jean jacket with sleeves cut off and a tattoo of the red and black wheel from which the Klan gets its name appeared on his shoulder, almost lost amid the flushed skin.

We froze. The sergeant, unarmed at the moment, stared the man down. He stared right back. Ever the diplomatic moron, I was about to ask cheerily if he could move the truck since we were leaving. But the awkward moment of collision continued until I began to inch out towards the door. As the man drew breath to speak, a station wagon loaded with supplies pulled up, producing two women in dark blue FEMA shirts.

"This stuff is due up north and the road is still blocked. We can't drive around it!"

I couldn't resist. "Hey. . .nice truck."

The man looked at the women, who then began pleading with him to let them drive north with the supplies. We quickly slipped outside, got into the behemoth and started it up.

"Hey! Where the hell do you think you're going?" His demand was angry but I doubt he was ready to go head-to-head with a platoon of soldiers and two federal employees.

The troops carried the boxes out of the car and dumped them in the back. The sergeant jumped in and we struck off north, driving around fallen trees as the Jeep followed behind.

Once clear of Ivanhoe, the sergeant began inspecting the content of the truck. He pulled a piece of beef jerky out of the cupholder along with a pair of sunglasses with a stylized cross on the rim and tossed them out the window.

"Don't need that. . .don't need that."

Down came the Confederate flag, which he similarly defenestrated.

"DEFINITELY don't need that."

We had a good laugh when we left the machine in Beaumont covered with mud and still missing its racist ornaments. Presumably, it was eventually collected by its owner. I still write with the sergeant, who called the commandeering "one of the most satisfying moments ever."

But the event did prove, unfortunately, that people like Hank Erwin and the Klansman will always be willing to assert themselves in even the most dire of circumstances. We should always be ready for them.

Dar'a, Syria - February 2006

European inroads into the world around them yielded great gains of territory and riches until the world got smaller in recent decades. The Germans and Italians lost their African holdings in the world wars of the early twentieth century while French, Belgium and the Netherlands had their empires chipped away at by revolts, releases and lack of interest. Spain was relieved of its riches before the twentieth century began and Portugal had only Macau until it was returned to the Chinese.

But the British Empire was the largest and most widespread at the end of the day. British ships, roads and communications were the finest in the world and its lands and the people on it produced textiles, minerals and oil along with an infinite market for British manufactured goods. When it finally collapsed in the last half of the twentieth century, the borders between countries which had never existed before created the finest, longest and most destructive wars this planet has ever seen. You can't help but be impressed.

But one of the most enduring gifts of the United Kingdom to the world is the pound, its prized unit of currency. The issue of giving up the British pound sterling for the European Union's common currency is still in contention and has been put off more times than the Eagles' farewell tour. And although the value of the pound sterling is not common (it is nearly US$2), the name is.

I forgot this during a rather trying day in the highlands of Jordan while crossing into Syria. I was driving a rickety old bus with two aid workers and two people who had gotten medical care in Jordan. We were trying to back west but our map was useless. After three hours, we had done two complete circles and taken numerous wrong turns. Since we were low on fuel, it was a relief to see the Syrian flag so we could figure out where the hell we were.

A man at the Jordanian side said we could get where we were going if we crossed the border and took the northwest road. After the Jordanian guards went through the bus and waved us on, we were stopped at the Syrian gate and questioned by the company captain. He didn't speak English but we managed to get on in French. He gave me directions and cleared us to enter but then, for some reason, asked me for "trois cents livres."

"Three hundred books?"

"Non, trois cents LIVRES." He reached into his pocket and pulled a green piece of paper out.

"Pounds? Three hundred POUNDS?!"

Crap. What kind of dung-hill backwater country has a 300-pound crossing fee? That's almost US$600! It had to be a scam. He had to be pocketing it, but I didn't know how to get around. I went into the back of the bus and asked everyone for all the money they could put together, figuring that we could work it out later. I didn't know how yet, since the reason we were in Amman is because the two people didn't have insurance. Between the five of us, we had about US$400 in six different currencies.

"This is going to work out just great," I muttered as I reached out the window with my hat full of money. He looked at questioningly and looked at my pleasantly smiling face as if he was about to back away and call the funny farm. I pointed to the hat, saying it was all we had. He reached into the hat like a country fair queen looking for the winning ticket. Eventually, the hand emerged with a five-dollar bill. He smiled, thanked me and raised the gate.

What the. . .? I didn't care. I stepped on it, getting safely into Syria and down the correct road before he could change his mind. However, once I stopped for gasoline, I was faced with a similar predicament. The attendant asked me for 900 pounds. I was about to start yelling at him until I saw someone getting change and noticed English writing on the back of the notes. I peered into the cash register to read it.

"Central Bank of Syria, One Hundred Syrian Pounds."

The 300 pounds the border guard asked for equaled about US$5.50, about a hundredth of what I thought he meant. As it turned out, Syria, Cyprus, Egypt and many other countries in the area late of the British Empire kept the currency name "pound," even though the local value was nowhere near the British pound sterling.

I returned the money in my hat to its rightful owners, who scowled at me for being so monumentally stupid.

However, I felt better upon my return to the United States. I discovered that our dollar sign is from the early days of our country's independence, when the Bank of the United States switched from the pound to the dollar and placed the letters "U" and "S" on top of each other as the symbol of the U.S. currency. After a typographical error cut the bottom of the "U" off in a printing press, we were left with a "S" split by two vertical lines. This was later reduced to one for simplicity's sake, giving the world "$." So every nation that uses the dollar as their currency (Canada, Australia, New Zealand, the Solomon Islands, Guyana, the Bahamas, Hong Kong, Fiji, Taiwan and Jamaica, just to name a few) is also using the symbol for the U.S. dollar, even though no dollar in the world is worth as much as ours. This oversight leads to an estimated 30 errors per day in the currency market industry, leading to millions of dollars appearing and disappearing for no clear reason.

So when you fall victim to currency confusion because some people aren't creative enough to make up their own name, don't feel bad. Even the professionals get it wrong sometimes.
